Course Objectives:

This course explores the art and methods of systems programming. Practically speaking, lectures and course assignments will provide students with experience programming in C within the UNIX environment. UNIX tools will be introduced, as will the general UNIX philosophy. Use of the Linux command line will be taught to proficiency. We will examine the use of shell programs, compilers, build sequences, memory management, file systems, signal processing, parallel programming, and other topics essential to computer scientists. In addition, we will introduce students to the basics of systems administration on UNIX virtual machines.

A detailed list of lectures by lecture contents, assignments, and due dates (subject to change as the semester evolves) is available on the Module page.

Format of Meetings 

The instructional delivery for this course will be conducted in person unless the university decides to transition to an online mode. Two sections are scheduled in the afternoons on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays.

All three examinations must be taken within the physical classroom setting, and no online alternatives will be provided.

 

Communication

General messages will be disseminated through Canvas Announcements. For queries that need to be answered elsewhere, it is advised to contact the Teaching Assistant (TA) initially. If the TA cannot address your question, you may direct your inquiry to the instructor or have your TA relay the question to the instructor. 

We will utilize Campuswire as the platform for class discussions. To participate, kindly sign up and join Campuswire using the group code 2607. Students are strongly encouraged to register using their .psu email ID. It is important to exercise discretion and refrain from posing questions that may reveal crucial aspects of assignments. Additionally, please exhibit courtesy, and before posting, check previous threads to ascertain if your question has already been addressed. The following rules apply:

  1. You are welcome to pose questions related to lectures or assignments.
  2. Refrain from sharing your code, program output, or any solutions. Save such discussions for office hours with the course staff.
  3. Conceptual questions may be shared publicly but exercise sound judgment.
  4. If you are confident in your knowledge, it is acceptable to provide answers to your fellow students' questions.

Course Philosophy

System programming concerns the development of software and services used by applications and operating systems, e.g., OS functions, defragmenter, web servers, databases, search tools, backup systems, etc. This course will provide the information and experience required to understand, design, and implement components of large and small software systems.

In general, students successfully completing the course will be able to evaluate design alternatives according to engineering best practices, specifications, performance analysis, robustness, etc. This course will investigate one system and one programming language in detail through demonstrations, programs, programming assignments, etc. The specific system is Unix, a family of operating systems forming a complete standardized programming environment based on the idea of software tools. The specific language is C, which is widely used for operating system implementations, and which forms the basis for the C++ and Java languages studied in the prerequisite courses. This will help students understand operating system services available to application programmers, and provide a firm ground for the study of operating systems in general.

IMPORTANT: This course covers the basic skills and topics that form the foundation of later CMPSC and CMPEN courses. For this reason, it is essential that every student attend and learn the material. It will be nearly impossible for students to complete later courses in these majors without mastery of this material.

Exam Policy: Make-Up and Conflict Exam

Please note the following policy regarding exams for this course:
  1. Conflict/Make-Up Exam:
    • There will be only one conflict/Makeup exam.
      A conflict/Make-up exam will be offered only to students with a verified scheduling conflict and health issue.
    • To be eligible, students must provide appropriate documentation as proof of the conflict and other reasons.
  2. Penalties for Missing the Conflict/Make-Up Exam:
    • If you cannot attend the conflict/Make-Up exam, and request another conflict/Make-Up exam, 
      you will get a 25% penalty on points. This is a department wise policy.
Unless you have a genuine scheduling conflict or health issue, we strongly encourage all students to attend the main exam. Once again. We ask for your cooperation in adhering to this policy to ensure fairness for everyone. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact us.

Course Projects

The course projects require students to develop and debug system programs. The details of the projects will be made in class and through project descriptions made available on the course website.

 

Class Participation

Attendance and active class participation are strongly encouraged. Should you have any uncertainties regarding a particular topic, we encourage you to seek clarification by posing questions to the instructor either during or after the class. A maximum of 2 additional points will be granted as a reward for active engagement, augmenting your final grade. Participation in class activities will be facilitated through the use of Top Hat.

 

Weekly Quiz Participation

We will publish a quiz with a microlearning package every week. This quiz is created using the materials covered in the previous week of the course. Its purpose is to motivate students to review the material and prepare for the exams. We strongly recommend that students study the materials, complete weekly quizzes, and compare their answers with the provided solutions weekly.  A maximum of 2 additional points will be rewarded for participating in the quizzes.

Academic Integrity Course Policy

The course projects are to be carried out individually. Students are explicitly not allowed to share information, source code, or even discuss the contents of the projects. Any violation of this policy will be considered cheating and will result in the student receiving an 'F' grade for the project and a full letter grade off the final grade for the course. Students with more than one violation may face stronger penalties per the university policy.

Students are forbidden from copying code, makefiles, or any other material from the Internet (such as publicly available Github repos). Plagiarism will be strictly enforced by the TAs through in-depth reviews of your submissions. Any violation in the letter or spirit of this policy will also be considered cheating and handled as described above. Note that any publication of the assignments (e.g., via github or other system) is considered a violation of the above policy.

More information on The Department of Computer Science and Engineering’s Academic Integrity Standards, which are applicable to this course, can be found at https://www.eecs.psu.edu/students/resources/EECS-CSE-Academic-Integrity.aspx

Lateness Policy

Lab assignments are assessed a 10% per day late penalty, up to a maximum of three days after which a zero grade will be given. No exceptions. Period.  Note that the last lab will not have a three-day grace period as we need to finish the grading of this lab as soon as possible and make time for the grading of the final exam.

Virtual Machines/Student Computer

As part of the course projects, every student will be required to maintain a virtual machine on a personal computer. Students are responsible for administrating and maintaining these virtual machines and are strongly encouraged to back them up frequently.

It is the student's responsibility to have a functioning and suitably powerful computer to run their virtual machines. Hardware or software failures are the student's responsibility, and can not be used as an excuse for late assignments. The minimum requirements for this computer that has 100MB of free storage, 8GB of memory, and a 64-bit processor. Netbooks and tablets are not suitable.

Course Prerequisites

You must have completed and passed (with a grade of C or better) the prerequisite course CMPSC 221, Object-Oriented Programming with Web-Based Applications, which uses Java. You must have completed and passed (C or better) the earlier courses CMPSC 131 and 132. If, instead, you have completed and passed similar courses elsewhere, contact the instructor. Prior experience with Unix or C is not expected, but you should be very familiar with the concepts introduced in CMPSC 131 and 132 and know how to use an integrated development environment, e.g., Microsoft's Visual Studio.

If possible, you should take CMPEN 331, Computer Organization and Design, at the same time as this course, or within one semester of it. The connection between these courses would be stronger if we could require you to take both at the same time, but that's not possible. In 331, you learn about the basics of memory organization (registers, cache, main memory, virtual memory), instruction execution, exceptions and interrupts, and the translation of procedural programming languages into machine instructions.

This is a three-credit course, and you can expect to spend a lot of time outside of class working on the project programming. To avoid turning the programming assignments into a nightmare of unsuccessful debugging, you should recognize symptoms of confusion early and promptly ask for help from the professors or TA. With the exception of first and second assignments, the following assignments will build on previous assignments, so incomplete or poor code will make later assignments very difficult if not impossible. For this reason, it is essential students do not get behind on the projects.

We will often give you some code as examples or as a starter kit for an assignment, and the use of that material is encouraged. After that point, the programming work should be done on your own. This will be strictly enforced.

Course Ethics

This course considers topics involving systems. As part of this investigation, we will cover technologies whose abuse may infringe on the rights of others. As an instructor, I rely on the ethical use of these technologies. Unethical use may include circumvention of existing security or privacy measurements for any purpose or the dissemination, promotion, or exploitation of vulnerabilities of these services. Exceptions to these guidelines may occur in the process of reporting vulnerabilities through public and authoritative channels. Any activity outside the letter or spirit of these guidelines will be reported to the proper authorities and may result in dismissal from the class.

Any instance of sharing or plagiarism, copying, cheating on tests, or other disallowed behavior will constitute a breach of ethics and will result in the penalty identified above. Programming assignments must be completed without assistance or cooperation between students.

Students are responsible for reporting any violation of these rules by other students, and failure to constitutes an ethical violation that carries with it similar penalties.

When in doubt, please contact the course professor for advice. Do not undertake any action which could be perceived as technology misuse or cheating anywhere and/or under any circumstances unless you have received explicit permission from Professor Suman Saha.

Disability Accommodation

Penn State welcomes students with disabilities into the University’s educational programs. Every Penn State campus has an office for students with disabilities. Student Disability Resources (SDR) website provides contact information for every Penn State campus (http://equity.psu.edu/sdr/disability-coordinator).

For further information, please visit the Student Disability Resources website (http://equity.psu.edu/sdr).

In order to receive consideration for reasonable accommodations, you must contact the appropriate disability services office at the campus where you are officially enrolled, participate in an intake interview, and provide documentation: See documentation guidelines (http://equity.psu.edu/sdr/guidelines).

If the documentation supports your request for reasonable accommodations, your campus disability services office will provide you with an accommodation letter.

Please share this letter with your instructors and discuss the accommodations with them as early as possible. You must follow this process for every semester that you request accommodations.

 

Counseling And Psychological Services

Many students at Penn State face personal challenges or have psychological needs that may interfere with their academic progress, social development, or emotional well-being. The university offers confidential services to help you through difficult times, including individual and group counseling, crisis intervention, consultations, online chats, and mental health screenings. These services are provided by staff who welcome all students and embrace a philosophy that respects clients’ cultural and religious backgrounds and is sensitive to differences in race, ability, gender identity, and sexual orientation.

Counseling and Psychological Services at University Park (CAPS) (http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling): 814-863-0395

Penn State Crisis Line (24 hours/7 days/week): 877-229-6400

Crisis Text Line (24 hours/7 days/week): Text LIONS to 741741

Educational Equity Concerns: Consistent with University Policy AD29, students who believe they have experienced or observed a hate crime, an act of intolerance, discrimination, or harassment that occurs at Penn State are urged to report these incidents as outlined in the University’s Report Bias webpage (http://equity.psu.edu/reportbias)

 

Appropriate Behavior Expectations

Sexual misconduct is never tolerated at Penn State. Prohibited conduct includes sexual and gender-based harassment, stalking, sexual assault, and dating violence. These behaviors are not allowed in the classroom, the campus community, labs, or anywhere students, staff, and faculty are located. Prohibited behaviors can include degrading comments such as belittling female-identified students, LGBTQ+ individuals, and gender-diverse students, People of Color, and other marginalized students. It can also include harassment, touching someone without their consent, following someone without consent, repeated calls or messaging, physical acts of violence, and more. In other words, professional and appropriate behavior is always expected, and inappropriate or unprofessional behavior is never tolerated. For more information, please refer to the Student Code of Conduct and Penn State Policies AD85 and AD91. (Title IX Sexual Harassment | Penn State Policies (psu.edu) and Discrimination and Harassment and Related Inappropriate Conduct | Penn State Policies (psu.edu))

If you or anyone you know has experienced or is concerned about inappropriate or unprofessional behavior, you can talk with your instructor, report to the police or the Office of Sexual Misconduct Reporting & Response (titleix.psu.edu), or you can seek confidential support and assistance from the Gender Equity Center. The Gender Equity Center supports any student who has had negative relationship experiences, including those impacted by sexual violence, relationship violence, stalking, harassment, and other campus climate issues. Services include one-on-one crisis intervention/support, advocacy, exploring options, accommodations, safety planning, and referrals. They also promote awareness, build support for survivors, and conduct educational programs and events. All services are free and confidential. Gender Equity Center | Penn State Student Affairs (psu.edu)

 

Educational Equity/Report Bias

Consistent with University Policy AD29, students who believe they have experienced or observed a hate crime, an act of intolerance, discrimination, or harassment that occurs at Penn State are urged to report these incidents as outlined on the University’s Report Bias webpage (http://equity.psu.edu/reportbias/)

The video and audio recordings are used for educational use/purposes and only may be made available to all students presently enrolled in the class. For purposes where the recordings will be used in future class session/lectures, any type of identifying information will be adequately removed.

courses.syllabus_body:
ACCTG 211 Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision Making

Course Description

The objective of this course is to introduce students to the discipline of accounting through an introduction to two of accounting's sub-disciplines, financial and managerial accounting. The more specific purpose is to provide students a basic understanding of the role of financial and managerial accounting information in the decisions of capital market participants external to a business enterprise (e.g., stockholders, banks, financial analysts, prospective stockholders), and in the decisions of those who manage business enterprises. Accounting information has an important role in the resource allocation process in our socioeconomic system as a whole, as well as in each individual business enterprise. This course provides students with an understanding of the nature of the accounting function, and how the information in accounting reports is used by various decision-makers in their resource allocation decisions. This course is an important background course for all business majors and numerous non-business majors.

TEXTBOOKS:

To subscribe for Computer Organization and Design textbook, it costs $72

 

1- Sign in or create an account at learn.zybooks.com

The first chapter of any zyBook is open to students without payment so everyone in the class can get started right away! If any student needs an extension in complimentary access beyond the first chapter, please follow these instructions to request longer access.

Zybook help center for students can be found here and is also linked via the help/FAQ button in the top right-hand corner of the zyBooks platform. 

 

REFERENCES:

  1. Andrew Tanenbaum and Todd Austin. Structured Computer Organization, 6th edition, Pearson
  2. Linda Null and Julia Lobur. The Essentials of Computer Organization and Architecture, 4th edition, Jones & Bartlett Learning.
  3. William Stallings, Computer Organization and Architecture, 10th edition, Pearson
  4. Carl Hamacher, Zvonko Vranesic, Safwat Zaky, Naraig Manjikian. Computer Organization and Embedded Systems, 6th edition, Mc Graw Hill
  5. Kip Irvine, Assembly Language for Intel-Based Computers, Prentice Hall. 

 

SOFTWARE TOOLS:

  • MARS, Xilinx Vivado.
  • For the assembly language, you will need an environment in which you can edit, assemble, link and run assembly-language programs. We will use a Freeware simulator called MARS to support the required assembly language programming. This software is available for download from the following link MARS "https://dpetersanderson.github.io", MARS itself has a nice Help feature. “http://courses.missouristate.edu/KenVollmar/MARS/”.
  • For the Verilog language, you will need to use Xilinx Vivado/ModelSim. This is available in w136 Westgate building. You can also download Vivado (It is available for windows machine and it is not available for Mac). Instructions for downloading the Vivado WebPack version can be found here: “ https://www.xilinx.com/support/download.html”. Xilinx has a strict internal export control policy which blocks users from E or D category countries. Check this file for more details: https://www.bis.doc.gov/index.php/documents/regulation-docs/2255-supplement-no-1-to-part-740-country-groups-1/file.
  • Students are facing different issues while installing Vivado. So, I request everyone to complete the installation as soon as possible.
  • It is very recommended to install Vivado as all the labs hints are using this software. However, students facing the Vivado license issue should install an alternative software called "Intel Quartus".
  • This is very uncommon but just to let you know that students who are outside the United States may face difficulties with respect to Vivado webpack installation due to license issues. They can install the Intel Quartus software instead. This problem occurred due to obligations of export controls and related license agreement restrictions for Vivado. In this case, students are not allowed to use any such controlled software even remotely if they are in a location forbidden by said agreements. Accordingly, you are not permitted to use Vivado even if you have the access to log in remotely to w135 in Westgate building or any other lab that you have access to here in the United States.
  • Follow the following steps to install Quartus software:
  • Go to this website: https://fpgasoftware.intel.com/?edition=lite.
  • Select Edition: Lite Select Release: 19.1
  • Go to combined files tab => Download .tar file
  • Extract the downloaded .tar file
  • Then, run "QuartusLiteSetup" file which should automatically install all other files.
  • If it asks for user sign in, then just create an account using college mail id and use it to sign in.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE REMOTE LOGIN TO W135 WESTGATE BUILDING:

 

The hostnames are e5-cse-135-01.cse.psu.edu through e5-cse-135-38.cse.psu.edu and can be accessed remotely once connected to the PSU Globalprotect vpn.  The Windows machines are not accessible remotely but are available at w136 Westgate.

Students need to connect to GlobalProtect vpn and then ssh to one of the w135 Linux machines.

 

COURSE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES:

 

Critical thinking, problem solving and information literacy: Students will use critical thinking and problem solving skills in analyzing information gathered through different media and from a variety of sources.

 By the end of the semester, successful student will be expected to Identify/Recognize:

  • Digital Logic Circuits and how data is represented
  • Computer organization
  • Assembler directives and the Instruction set
  • How to write small programs in assembly language and translate them to machine code
  • Combine basic digital circuitry components to process subsets of machine code
  • MIPS and data path with pipeline implementation
  • Verilog test bench and familiarity with Zynq 7000 Development Board
  • Memory Hierarchy
  • Storage and I/O devices

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

REQUIRED WORK

 

Homework

Problems will be assigned weekly or biweekly. Late homework will not receive any credit. However, you have the permission to miss one of the homework without penalty. You have to solve the online problems in the zyBooks website (https://www.zybooks.com). Some of the problems will be assigned in advance of covering their corresponding materials in class.

 

Exams

There will be three midterm exams. Each student is entitled to skip one exam due to official reasons without incurring any penalties. Consequently, no makeup exam will be granted for the first missed exam. You will only be eligible for a particular makeup exam if you have missed two or more exams due to official excuses. Please be aware that if you choose to miss one exam for personal reasons, it will count towards your official number of allowable excuses mentioned earlier. It is strongly recommended not to miss any exams unless you have an official excuse. Official excuses need to be approved by the instructor in advance. Please refer to the 'Guidelines for Makeup Examinations' for further information. I will not respond to any email that requesting a makeup exam unless it satisfies the aforementioned policy.

 

Quizzes

6 – 9 pre-announced quizzes will be given during the semester, (no makeups, unless you have more than a defined number of official excuses), I will not respond to any email that requesting a makeup quiz unless it satisfies the aforementioned policy.  Every student will have a defined number, in advance, of excuses to use them for skipping any defined number of quizzes if needed (these can be personal or official excuses). Meaning that, I will drop the lowest defined number of scores. This defined number is currently equal to two and it could increase in the future. You must take a permission in advance from the instructor if you would like to take your quiz with another section. Cheating on any QUIZ will result in 0 grade on that QUIZ.

 

Labs

Lab assignments will be assigned on canvas. Late submissions will incur a penalty of 2% per day, up to a maximum of 5 days (with one minute being equivalent to one day). It is advisable to adhere to timely submission and refrain from relying on the available late submission days. Your proactive approach to meeting deadlines is highly encouraged. No submission will be accepted after the 5th day of the due date. TAs or LAs (if any) will grade the submitted zipped file to canvas. Please expect that we might pick randomly some students to grade their submitted labs through one to one meeting with the grader. In this case, your answers have to match your submission and you need to show your understanding of your solution. Your GRADE will depend solely on your answers to the grader(s) questions in that particular lab. The same apply for the project stated in the next item.

 

Project

There will be one project. This project due date will be posted online, late submission will not be accepted.

 

Guidelines for Makeup Examinations or Delayed Assignment Submission:

- A self-report or standard doctor's appointment is not considered an acceptable reason or suffice as an excuse.

 

- Evidence from an in-person visit with a healthcare practitioner, explicitly demonstrating the inability to partake in the exam/quiz as originally scheduled, is necessary.

 

- It must be emphasized that under these circumstances too, notifications regarding excuses have to be delivered at least 24 hours before the designated assignment due date. This is crucial as late submission requests beyond the assignment deadline or approved grace period will not be accommodated.

 

-An email petition sent by a student on the day of or one day prior to the exam requesting a makeup examination does not ensure automatic acceptance by the instructor.

 

-Unexcused absence from an examination without prior consent of the instructor will disqualify students from being allowed a makeup opportunity regardless of their situation.

 

GRADING:

Homework: 5%

Labs: 20%

Quizzes: 25%

Exam 1: 15% (Tentative: Week of February 24th in class)

Exam 2: 15% (Tentative: Week of March 31st in class)

Exam 3: 15% (Tentative: Week of April 21st in class)

Project: 5 %

 

GRADING DISTRIBUTION:

A  100-94                    B+  < 90 - 86               C+  < 77 - 73               D  < 68 - 61

A-  <94- 90                  B    < 86 - 81               C     < 73 - 68              F   < 61 - 0

                                    B-    < 81-77                                       

 

COURSE POLICIES

 

Engaging in academic dishonesty during any examination will result in a grade of 0 for that specific examination. Violations will be subject to academic integrity consequences, which may include failure of the course in certain instances. This applies also to quizzes, problem sets, labs or project. 

 

While we will make every effort to communicate both in person and online, students are responsible for being aware of any in-person announcements that may not have been posted online

 

Cell phones: All cell phones should either be turned off or set to a silent mode all the time. No phone calls or text messages may be sent within the classroom – if it is important to take a call or text, please leave the classroom to do so, and be prepared to make up the missed material outside of the class.

 

Laptops /Tablets: Please limit your activities on such devices to those which aid in your studies. It is your responsibility to maintain proper focus on the material being presented, as not all course material will be in electronic form.

 

Other devices: Unless otherwise permitted by the instructor, please keep other devices turned off during classroom activities.

 

Attendance Policy: Class attendance is one of the most important ways students learn and understand course materials. It is a critical element of student success. Class attendance recognizes on exceptional occasions.

 

Changes in syllabus and assignment sheets may be modified. All changes will be announced in class or/and online. 

EECS ACADEMIC INTEGRITY MODULE

The information is available on Canvas and includes additional details regarding the use of Generative AI tools. Please ensure that you complete all listed items, including the EECS Academic Integrity Quiz

 

ACCOMMODATIONS FOR STUDENTS WITH DISABILITIES     

Penn State welcomes students with disabilities into the University’s educational programs. Every Penn State campus has an office for students with disabilities. Student Disability Resources (SDR) website provides contact information for every Penn State campus. For further information, please visit Student Disability Resources website.

In order to receive consideration for reasonable accommodations, you must contact the appropriate disability services office at the campus where you are officially enrolled, participate in an intake interview, and provide documentation: See documentation guidelines. If the documentation supports your request for reasonable accommodations, your campus disability services office will provide you with an accommodation letter. Please share this letter with your instructors and discuss the accommodations with them as early as possible. You must follow this process for every semester that you request accommodations.

 

COUNSELING AND PSYCHOLOGICAL SERVICES

Many students at Penn State face personal challenges or have psychological needs that may interfere with their academic progress, social development, or emotional wellbeing. The university offers a variety of confidential services to help you through difficult times, including individual and group counseling, crisis intervention, consultations, online chats, and mental health screenings. These services are provided by staff who welcome all students and embrace a philosophy respectful of clients’ cultural and religious backgrounds, and sensitive to differences in race, ability, gender identity and sexual orientation.

Counseling and Psychological Services at University Park  (CAPS)  
(http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/): 814-863-0395  

  

Counseling and Psychological Services at Commonwealth Campuses  
(https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses)  

Penn State Crisis Line (24 hours/7 days/week): 877-229-6400
Crisis Text Line (24 hours/7 days/week): Text LIONS to 741741

 

EDUCATIONAL EQUITY/REPORT BIAS STATEMENTS

Penn State University has adopted a “Protocol for Responding to Bias Motivated Incidents” that is grounded in the policy that the “University is committed to creating an educational environment which is free from intolerance directed toward individuals or groups and strives to create and maintain an environment that fosters respect for others.” That policy is embedded within an institution traditionally committed to
academic freedom Bias motivated incidents include conduct that is defined in University
Policy AD 91: Discrimination and Harassment, and Related Inappropriate Conduct. Students, faculty, or staff who experience or witness a possible bias motivated incident are urged to report the incident immediately by doing one of the following:

* Submit a report via the Report Bias webpage
* Contact one of the following offices:

University Police Services, University Park: 814-863-1111
Multicultural Resource Center, Diversity Advocate for Students: 814-865-1773
Office of the Vice Provost for Educational Equity: 814-865-5906
Office of the Vice President for Student Affairs: 814-865-0909
Affirmative Action Office: 814-863-0471

* Dialing 911 in cases where physical injury has occurred or is imminent

 

ACADEMIC INTEGRITY STATEMENT

Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at The Pennsylvania State University, and all members of the University community are expected to act in accordance with this principle.

 

According to Penn State policy G-9: Academic Integrity, an academic integrity violation is “an intentional, unintentional, or attempted violation of course or assessment policies to gain an academic advantage or to advantage or disadvantage another student academically.” Unless your instructor tells you otherwise, you must complete all course work entirely on your own, using only sources that have been permitted by your instructor, and you may not assist other students with papers, quizzes, exams, or other assessments. If your instructor allows you to use ideas, images, or word phrases created by another person (e.g., from Course Hero or Chegg) or by generative technology, such as ChatGPT, you must identify their source. You may not submit false or fabricated information, use the same academic work for credit in multiple courses, or share instructional content. Students with questions about academic integrity should ask their instructor before submitting work.

Students facing allegations of academic misconduct may not drop/withdraw from the affected course unless they are cleared of wrongdoing (see G-9: Academic Integrity). Attempted drops will be prevented or reversed, and students will be expected to complete course work and meet course deadlines. Students who are found responsible for academic integrity violations face academic outcomes, which can be severe, and put themselves at jeopardy for other outcomes which may include ineligibility for Dean’s List, pass/fail elections, and grade forgiveness. Students may also face consequences from their home/major program and/or The Schreyer Honors College.

 

Appropriate behavior expectations

Sexual misconduct is never tolerated at Penn State. Prohibited conduct includes sexual and gender-based harassment, stalking, sexual assault, and dating violence. These behaviors are not allowed in the classroom, the campus community, labs, or anywhere students, staff, and faculty are located. Prohibited behaviors can include degrading comments such as belittling female-identified students, LGBTQ+ individuals, and gender-diverse students. It can also include harassment, touching someone without their consent, following someone without consent, repeated calls or messaging, physical acts of violence, and more. In other words, professional and appropriate behavior is always expected, and inappropriate or unprofessional behavior is never tolerated. For more information, please refer to the Student Code of Conduct and Penn State Policies AD85 and AD91. (Title IX Sexual Harassment | Penn State Policies (psu.edu) and Discrimination and Harassment and Related Inappropriate Conduct | Penn State Policies (psu.edu)) 

 

If you or anyone you know has experienced or is concerned about inappropriate or unprofessional behavior, you can talk with College, or School leadership, your instructor, academic advisor, or another trusted faculty/staff member, report to police or the Office of Sexual Misconduct Reporting & Response (titleix.psu.edu), or you can seek confidential support and assistance from the Gender Equity Center. The Gender Equity Center supports any student who has had negative relationship experiences including those impacted by sexual violence, relationship violence, stalking, harassment, and other campus climate issues. Services include one on one crisis intervention/support, advocacy, exploring options, accommodations, safety planning, and referrals. They also promote awareness, build support for survivors, and conduct educational programs and events. All services are free and confidential. Gender Equity Center | Penn State Student Affairs (psu.edu) 

 

 

* Source: http://keepteaching.psu.edu/ and https://senate.psu.edu/ as of 12/5/22  

* Last updated February 2, 2024 

 

 

Whom should I contact if I need additional assistance?

I encourage you to contact your academic adviser for specific needs you might have outside this course.  Academic adviser information and scheduling can be found at starfish.psu.edu.

 

How will I get updated information from PSU?

As the instructor for this course, I strongly encourage you to abide by the requirements Penn State has communicated regarding testing and returning to campus. This information is evolving, but you can find the latest here. Check your PSU email and the Penn State Go app daily for updates from the University, your college, department, and instructors. We use your PSU email address to make sure you have the most up-to-date information. It will be very important for you to check Penn State’s keeplearning.psu.edu page for helpful information about the Spring semester.

Dear Students,

We have identified nine AI violations in Lab #2 involving 12 students. Discussions with the students involved will begin after the spring break. Until these cases are resolved, their Lab #2 grades will be withheld. Any confirmed violations will be reported to the College of Engineering.

We use specialized detection tools to identify AI-generated or highly similar code, even when significant modifications are made. Our system can also determine whether the code was written using ChatGPT.

As a reminder, all course assignments must be completed individually. Sharing information, source code, or discussing project details with others is strictly prohibited. Any violation of this policy will be treated as academic misconduct, resulting in:

  • A grade of 'F' for the project
  • A complete letter grade deduction from the final course grade

I encourage you to uphold academic integrity, seek help through office hours and Campuswire, and focus on your efforts to overcome challenges.

We are always here to support you.

Best regards,
Dr. Saha

announcements.title: Lab 2 helper functions
announcements.message:
It has come to our attention that some students assume it is mandatory to create a helper function for Lab 2. However, this is not required. You are encouraged to write helper functions to simplify your implementation, but doing so is completely optional and not a requirement.

When writing your code, remember that there are always multiple valid ways to implement a solution. Some students may find a helpder function useful, while others may prefer a different approach and both are perfectly fine. The most important thing is that you write code that makes sense to you and aligns with your understanding of the problem.

It is crucial that your code is clear and understandable to you because, in future labs, you may need to revisit and modify your own implementation. Writing code in a way that is intuitive to you will make debugging and extending it much easier.

Do not write code just because someone told you that you "must" do it a certain way, especially if you do not fully understand it. Your implementation should reflect your thought process and intuition.

Please always refer to ReadMe_LAB2.pdf for official instructions. The details in the ReadMe take precedence over any assumptions or external discussions.  All necessary instructions for Lab 2 are provided there.

Let us know if you have any questions!

Final Exam Scheduled

  • ACCTG 211 Exam 5 will be taken during final exam week. ACCTG 211 is scheduled for Tuesday, May 6th, 8am - 11pm EST, in 107 Pollock Building.You will register to take the exam at a time anytime from 8am - 11pm EST. Please make sure when the registration opens you do not register to take your exam at a time you are scheduled to take another final exam.
  • Please note any conflict with Exam 5, taken during Final exam week, needs to be sent to the Registrar. The final exam conflict period ends this Sunday, March 9th.

Exam 2 Grades

Confirming the posting of the Module 2 Exam scores on Canvas and providing some follow-up information.  The median score for all students who took the Module 2 Exam was 73, and this is fairly consistent with past median scores during the spring semester when exams were given in the Pollock Testing Center. Great job with attending class (in-person or via WEB videos) and following the Read, Watch, Do, Review Process!! 

We conduct various checks after the conclusion of each exam in an effort to validate the exam scores prior to posting them to our Canvas grade book. As a result of this validation process and combined with observations that we made during the administration of the exam, we have decided to provide the equivalent points associated with one exam question as credit back to all students. 

Please note that we included the effect of this credit in your Module 2 Exam score when we uploaded the results to Canvas…so your Canvas score for the Module 2 Exam already includes the effect of these additional points. Some of you may notice that your exam score exceeds 100% as a result of these additional points. Canvas treats any amount in excess of 100% as extra credit in the course. If you are interested to review your exam, please sign-up via this link: Exam 2 Reviews.

We would like to remind you to make use of the "Grade Calculator" excel file to determine your current overall grade in the course. A reminder that Extra Credit assignments ONLY help your grade. Let's say you earn 50% on all extra credit assignments then at the end of the semester you would increase your grade by 2% i.e. possibly going from 88% to 90%. You have unlimited attempts on the Extra Credit assignments and we post the highest grade on Extra Credit assignments.  

The highest assignment grade for HW for Lesson 1 - Lesson 6 and for EC for Lesson 1 - Lesson 6 have been posted to Canvas. Please confirm you see your highest assignment grade for each of these assignments.  

Great job overall on the Module 2 Exam!  

~ Your ACCTG 211 Instructional Team.

  • Remember to continue working on the EP assignments (Extra Credit) in Connect as you are working on the HW assignments.  Although the assignments are not due until Tuesday, March 25th, we expect students to be working on the EP assignments as we conclude each lesson.  Just a reminder that these assignments are the only extra credit opportunity provided in the course.

announcements.title: Reminders: Exam 2
announcements.message:
Please note that the instructional team cannot answer content questions during the exam window (from 8AM Monday until 11PM Tuesday).  TODAY (Sunday 3/2) is your last opportunity to attend an office hour for help.  Please see Friday 2/28 Canvas announcement with office hours for Sunday 3/2!

 

ACCTG 211 Exam 2 on Lessons 4, 5, and 6, is scheduled for Monday, March 3rd and Tuesday, March 4th, to be taken in Pollock Testing Center.

  • Make sure you have received a confirmation email from eTesting confirming the time you selected for the exam. 
    • Do NOT miss your exam time. Arrive 30 minutes prior to your exam time. 
  • Exams are closed book/closed notes.
  • Please bring your student ID and a pencil or pen to the testing center.
  • The testing center will provide you with a basic calculator and a blank sheet of paper for you to use when taking your exam.
    • Please make sure you take a calculator when you check in to the exam.  You will turn in the sheet of paper when you exit the Pollock Testing Center.
  • You are not allowed to use your own calculator, only the basic calculator provided to you by the Pollock Testing Center.

 

Some important notes for the Module 2 Exam (65-minute exam):

1) you will be given 26 questions;

2) this means that you will have 2.5 minutes per question (on average) to complete the exam...some questions will take longer while other questions will take less time;

3) pace yourself properly, as the 65-minute time frame will move very quickly;

EXAM INFO-IMPORTANT

 Since the Pollock Testing Center has made some changes to their process, we wanted to reach out with some reminders. 

  1.  Plan to arrive 30 minutes before your scheduled time. Early is better than late! 
  1. Do not be late. You will NOT be admitted if you arrive late, even if you are only 1-2 minutes late. Since the center is full on our exam days, you probably will not find a time to reschedule. Failure to take the exam on Tuesday, will result in a 0.
  1. IF YOU MISS YOUR EXAM TIME-YOU WILL GET A 0 ON THE EXAM
  2. Since the exam will not launch automatically, you will need to click on the exam for it to launch. Please do this as soon as you are logged into Canvas. If you take too much time to launch the exam, you may not have the full time. The testing center is full on our exam days and the staff may ask you to leave if you go past your appointment time, even if you are not done with the exam.
  3. The exam can be found on the top of our canvas page 

Also…repeating previous reminders that the Testing Center will close at 11:00 pm EST, regardless of when you start your exam. 

Reminder:

Finally...repeating a previous reminder that we will not be able to answer any questions related to the content on the Module 2 Exam while the exam window is open (between 8AM Monday and 11PM Tuesday). We trust that you have been doing a great job in your exam preparations and we wish you well on the exam! No classes are held on exam day. You can do this!

assignments.name: Lab Assignment 0.5
assignments.description:
Due Jan. 31, 2025, by 11:59 pm, Points 100 (2% weight towards the final grade), Submitting a text entry box

Instructions

  • Log in to your virtual machine.
  • Click on this invitational link, and a private repository will be created for you after accepting the assignment. 
  • Follow the instructions from this document to set up your git environment.
  • To clone (i.e., download) the starter artifacts from a terminal in your virtual machine :
    • % mkdir cmpsc311
    • % cd cmpsc311
    • % git clone git@github.com:PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>.git
    • % cd sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>
    • [ START EDITING ]

 

   Once cloned, you will have the starter files in the sp25-labhalf-<your_github_username>.

  • To complete this assignment, you are to:
    1. Create a file named IDs
    2. Edit the IDs file and put your 9 digits PSU ID in the first line, and your PSU username in the second line. No other text or comment should be added to the file (A sample file with  fake PSU ID and username is provided).
  • To submit your changes via git (following the git instructions):
    1. Prepare your changes using the git add command
    2. Commit your changes with an appropriate message using git commit command
    3. Push your changes using the git push command
       
  • It is good practice to commit and push your code regularly if you run into issues with your machine (Note: you must commit all files marked as changed when running 'git status').

To turn in:

After completing the assignment, submit on Canvas the commit ID that should be graded without additional text/words/comments around it.

Note: To get the commit ID (7 digits) that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and then copy the commit ID from the Commits History page.

assignments.name: Lab Assignment 1
assignments.description:
Due Feb. 14, 2025, by 11:59 pm, Points 100 (9.6% weight towards the final grade), Submitting a text entry box

Available Jan. 31, 2025 - Feb. 17, 2025 at 11:59 pm 

Instructions

  • Log in to your virtual machine.
  • Click on this invitational link, and a private repository will be created for you after accepting the assignment. 
  • Clone the repository by running git clone git@github.com:PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/sp25-lab1-<your_github_username>.git
  • Read Lab1_ReadMe.pdf and start your implementation

Remember to push your code to your repository before the deadline. 

To turn in:

Commit and push your latest code to Github. Then, submit on Canvas the commit ID that should be graded with no additional text/word/comment around it.

Note: To get the commit ID that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and copy the commit ID (7 characters long ).

 

Grading Rubrics:  

  • Working code/Passing test cases: 95%
  • Descriptive/relevant comments: 5%

 Note:

  • If "make" generates errors or warnings or if your code enters an infinite loop, you will receive a 0 for this lab.
  • Failure to submit your commit ID on Canvas by the due date will result in a 0.
  • Penalties: 10% per day for late submission (up to 3 days)
  • The lab assignment will not be graded if it is more than 3 days late

 

Edit1: We have updated the ReadMe to correct the Armstrong example. 2 is an Armstrong number, so it should be cubed.

assignments.name: Lab Assignment 2
assignments.description:
Due Feb. 28, 2025, by 11:59 pm, Points 100 (9.6% weight towards the final grade), Submitting a text entry box

Available Feb. 14, 2025 - Mar. 3, 2025 at 11:59 pm 
Note: This lab has a checkpoint, whose deadline is Feb 23. There will be a 50% penalty for missing the checkpoint submission. You do not need to submit anything in Canvas for the checkpoint because we will download the last version in GitHub as your checkpoint version.  

Lab 2 is a critical part of this course, serving as the foundation for all future labs. Unlike Lab 1, which was a warm-up to C, Lab 2 is the main building block for Labs 3, 4, and 5. You will not be able to complete the later labs if you do not finish Lab 2.

It is very important that you read the instructions provided in the ReadMe_LAB2.pd carefully before starting this assignment.  Do not delay starting the assignment—plan your time wisely!
To help you better understand this lab we have created  a helper video which we hope you find useful: https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/CMPSC311%3A+Lab+2+Helper+Video/1_8xdlsxij 
Please do not use the video as a substitute for ReadMe.  

 

Instructions

  • Log in to your virtual machine.
  • Click on this invitational link, and a private repository will be created for you after accepting the assignment. 
  • Clone the repository by running git clone git@github.com:PSU-CMPSC311-SAHA/sp2-lab2-<your_github_username>.git
  • Read ReadMe_LAB2.pdf and start your implementation
  • Check the checkpoint requirement 

Remember to push your code to your repository before the deadline(s). 

To turn in:

Commit and push your latest code to Github. Then, submit on Canvas the commit ID that should be graded with no additional text/word/comment around it.

Note: To get the commit ID that you want to be graded (usually the latest one), go to your repository page on GitHub.com, click on the last column named "<#> commits" in the top right, and copy the commit ID (7 characters long ).

 

Grading Rubrics:  

  • Passing test cases: 95%
  • Adding meaningful descriptive comments: 5%
  • If you have any make errors or warnings or if the program is stuck in a loop, then you will receive a straight 0. Make sure your code does not have any make errors before submitting
  • If you do not submit your commit ID on Canvas, you will receive a straight 0
  • We will use the timestamp on Canvas when you submit your commit ID to assess any late penalty. If you push your work on time on github.com but submit the commit ID late on Canvas, your work will be considered late and will incur a late penalty.

assignments.name: Week #7
assignments.description:
Weekly Quiz and Extra Credit Opportunity

This quiz consists of 10 questions based on the topics covered so far in the class in the week, with a 10-minute time limit for completion. Participation in this quiz offers you the chance to earn extra credit. For detailed information about the weekly extra credit opportunities, please refer to the syllabus on Canvas (Syllabus for CMPSC 311: Intro Sys Prog - SP25).

Each week, you will have one quiz like this, focusing on the material covered during that week. As a reminder, this quiz is purely for extra credit and does not affect the general grading scheme.

To help you prepare, we are providing additional study materials each week. You can find these resources in the "Files" section of the Canvas course under the "Microlearning" folder. (Files (instructure.com))

This week's resources include:

  1. Flashcards: These flashcards highlight key concepts from the week's content, making them perfect for quick, focused study sessions.

  2. Short Summaries: These summaries offer a concise overview of each section's main points, ideal for quick review.

  3. Scenario-Based Activities: Engage with hands-on exercises designed to reinforce key concepts in lexical analysis while encouraging critical thinking.

New files will be added to the corresponding weekly folder in the "Microlearning" section on Canvas. Make sure to take advantage of these resources to enhance your learning and perform well on the quizzes!

assignments.name: EECS Academic Integrity Quiz
assignments.description:
This quiz is to help you check your understanding of ethical practices in engineering and what constitutes an academic integrity violation in the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. The quiz contains some basic multiple-choice and T/F questions about academic integrity policy, as well as scenarios in which you will be asked to determine whether the action described would be considered an AI violation.

NOTE: A score of 100% is required to pass the quiz and complete the module, which will unlock other content in the course. If you do not pass, go back and review the material in the module. You may retake the quiz as many times as necessary.

assignments.name: Lesson 1 HW (Graded)
assignments.description:
Homework (20% of grade)

Graded homework (HW) is assigned for each of the 12 Lessons of the course through McGraw-Hill Connect. There will be 12 homework opportunities. You will have unlimited attempts at each homework (i.e. you can do the HW as many times as you wish before the deadline), and your highest homework score will be used in determining your final grade.

A "Check Answer" button is available. Clicking this button will reveal if you have successfully completed the assignment question. You will have five attempts to check your answer when navigating each graded assignment question. After five attempts, if you want to earn a higher grade on that assignment you will have to restart the assignment.

Each homework must be completed by the due date/time established in the Course Calendar. Once a graded homework closes, it cannot be re-opened for any reason. However, students can continue to review their submitted homework as part of their continued practice of the course material.

If you want to keep practicing the homework assignment after the due date, please refer to the respective "Study Attempts" assignment. You do not earn points via the "Study Attempts" assignment, but it allows you to continue to practice the problems after the homework due date.

To assist students with any technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness during a Lesson, we will drop the two lowest Homework scores earned. Therefore, the 10 highest Homework scores will be used toward your final grade, and each assignment is worth 2%.

assignments.name: Lesson 1 EP (Extra Credit)
assignments.description:
Extra Credit (up to 4%)

Students may earn extra credit by completing the Lesson Extra Practice (EP) via McGraw-Hill Connect for each Lesson. There are 12 EP (Extra Credit) opportunities, one for each of the 12 Lessons of the course. Each EP (Extra Credit) allows you to earn up to 0.33% extra credit toward your final course grade. You may take each EP (Extra Credit) an unlimited number of times, and the highest score will be used toward the Extra Credit (for example: if your highest score on an EP assignment for the Lesson is 90%, you would earn 90% of .33, or .297, in Extra Credit toward your final grade).

All of the EP (Extra Credit) for a Module will stay open until 11:59 p.m. on the night before the scheduled exam (see the Course Calendar for specific dates/times). The EP (Extra Credit) is designed to be attempted/taken at the completion of each Lesson. You may also take them again in the days before an Exam for study purposes; however, please do not wait until the last days before an exam to attempt all of the EP (Extra Credit) for the first time for the entire Module. If you do, you may find there is not enough time to complete them and/or fully understand the Lesson material.

Once the EP (Extra Credit) close, it cannot be re-opened for any reason, and there will be no further Extra Credit opportunities for that Module. Likewise, extensions will not be granted for EP (Extra Credit) for any reason, including technical issues, personal extenuating circumstances, or illness. Plan ahead and complete at least one attempt at each EP (Extra Credit) at the end of each Lesson throughout your study of the material, so you do not lose your Extra Credit opportunity due to an emergency at the end of the Module.

assignments.name: Exam_1_ACCTG211_SP25 - Requires Respondus LockDown Browser
assignments.description:
Following is the Smeal College of Business Honor Code:

We, the Smeal College of Business community, aspire to the highest ethical standards and will hold each other accountable to them. We will not engage in any action that is improper or that creates the appearance of impropriety in our academic lives, and we intend to hold this standard in our future careers.

 

According to the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct:

Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at Penn State University, allowing the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. According to the University’s Code of Conduct, you must neither engage in nor tolerate academic dishonesty. This includes, but is not limited to cheating, plagiarism, fabrication of information or citations, facilitating acts of academic dishonesty by others, unauthorized possession of examinations, submitting work of another person, or work previously used in another course without informing the instructor, or tampering with the academic work of other students.

The disciplinary process and your rights regarding academic integrity are outlined in Penn State’s University Faculty Senate Policy 49-20 and are supplemented by Penn State’s Office of Undergraduate Education Procedure G-9.

While this is not an exhaustive list, following are a few examples of actions during the examination process that could result in an Honor Code violation: 1) accessing items that you have been asked to place in the Testing Center’s approved green-colored drawstring bags; 2) accessing an unapproved examination aid; 3) using a calculator other than the calculator provided to you during the exam check-in process; 4) reproducing exam questions for other parties or transmitting exam questions to other parties; 5) entering the testing center restroom facility with your cell phone, scratch paper, exam ticket, or any unapproved examination aid; and 6) leaving the Testing Center with your scratch paper or exam ticket.

By clicking on the "Take the Quiz" button below, you implicitly certify that you have not engaged in any action that conflicts with the Smeal College of Business Honor Code or the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct prior to the start of the exam, and you further implicitly certify that you will abide by the Smeal College of Business Honor Code and the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct during the exam.

Copyright 2022 Schalyn Sohn and Kristy Schenck.  No portion of this exam may be used for commercial purposes, reproduced, published, broadcast, rewritten for broadcast or publication, or redistributed directly or indirectly in any medium without the express written permission of the authors.

By clicking on the "Take the Quiz" button below, you implicitly certify that you have not engaged in any action that conflicts with the Smeal College of Business Honor Code or the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct prior to the start of the exam, and you further implicitly certify that you will abide by the Smeal College of Business Honor Code and the Penn State Principles and University Code of Conduct during the exam.

assignments.name: PS5
assignments.description:
Solve the following from the computer organization zybook: (50 %)

  • Participation and challenging activities from 3.1 - 3.5.

Please submit your responses in the form of a PDF document to the following questions. (50 %)

1-Advancements in FPGA technology have enabled improved computational capabilities at lower costs. What are the implications of these advancements and how could they benefit society? (This is an open-ended question that encourages discussion. It may require you to conduct research through various means such as the internet, library resources, and more to gather the necessary information and formulate your response).

2-In our class discussion, we talked about the historical progression of computing systems. What about the environmental and social implications of the trajectory it’s on. Additionally, think about some potential future developments that could come out of it and discuss an application that could be built which we don’t yet see. Explain what the implications of that are in more detail. (250-word minimum)

assignments.name: EECS Academic Integrity Quiz
assignments.description:
This quiz is to help you check your understanding of ethical practices in engineering and what constitutes an academic integrity violation in the School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. The quiz contains some basic multiple-choice and T/F questions about academic integrity policy, as well as scenarios in which you will be asked to determine whether the action described would be considered an AI violation.

NOTE: A score of 100% is required to pass the quiz and complete the module, which will unlock other content in the course. If you do not pass, go back and review the material in the module. You may retake the quiz as many times as necessary.

quizzes.title: Week #1
quizzes.description:
Weekly Quiz and Extra Credit Opportunity

This quiz consists of 10 questions based on the topics covered so far in the class in the week, with a 10-minute time limit for completion. Participation in this quiz offers you the chance to earn extra credit. For detailed information about the weekly extra credit opportunities, please refer to the syllabus on Canvas (Syllabus for CMPSC 311: Intro Sys Prog - SP25).

Each week, you will have one quiz like this, focusing on the material covered during that week. As a reminder, this quiz is purely for extra credit and does not affect the general grading scheme.

To help you prepare, we are providing additional study materials each week. You can find these resources in the "Files" section of the Canvas course under the "Microlearning" folder. (Files (instructure.com))

This week's resources include:

  1. Flashcards: These flashcards highlight key concepts from the week's content, making them perfect for quick, focused study sessions.

  2. Short Summaries: These summaries offer a concise overview of each section's main points, ideal for quick review.

  3. Scenario-Based Activities: Engage with hands-on exercises designed to reinforce key concepts in lexical analysis while encouraging critical thinking.

New files will be added to the corresponding weekly folder in the "Microlearning" section on Canvas. Make sure to take advantage of these resources to enhance your learning and perform well on the quizzes!
